title: Camera Angle Psychology Database
description: Psychological effects and emotional impacts of different camera angles

vertical_angles.psychological_effect: Overwhelming power, intimidation, monumentality, divine/demonic presence
vertical_angles.power_dynamic: Subject has extreme power over viewer
vertical_angles.technical_notes: Camera often on ground. Creates distortion with wide lenses. Use sparingly for maximum impact.

vertical_angles.audience_feeling: Looking up to character, respect, admiration (or fear)
vertical_angles.power_dynamic: Subject has power, viewer is subordinate
vertical_angles.technical_notes: Most common power angle. Can be subtle (15°) or dramatic (45°). Works for both heroes and villains.

vertical_angles.character_perception: Equal to viewer, relatable, human, accessible
vertical_angles.power_dynamic: Equal footing between subject and viewer
vertical_angles.technical_notes: Most common angle. Creates audience-character equality. Baseline for comparison with other angles.
film_examples: Most dialogue scenes in most films

vertical_angles.audience_feeling: Looking down on character, sympathy, pity, or superiority
vertical_angles.technical_notes: Creates sympathy or emphasizes weakness. Subtle angles for gentle effect, steep for dramatic emphasis.
film_examples: Lord of the Rings (Frodo feeling small)

vertical_angles.psychological_effect: God's perspective, fate, insignificance, surveillance, detachment
vertical_angles.character_perception: Tiny, insignificant, part of larger pattern, fated, watched
vertical_angles.audience_feeling: Omniscient observer, detached, clinical, divine perspective
vertical_angles.technical_notes: Requires crane, drone, or high vantage point. Flattens space. Very distinctive, use sparingly.

vertical_angles.psychological_effect: Surveillance, pattern, geometry, voyeurism, clinical observation
vertical_angles.character_perception: Object to be observed, part of pattern, specimen
vertical_angles.power_dynamic: Complete viewer dominance, subject as object
vertical_angles.technical_notes: Perfectly 90° top-down. Removes depth dimension. Very stylized. Signature of certain directors.

vertical_angles.psychological_effect: Extreme power, overwhelm, monumentality, ant's perspective
vertical_angles.technical_notes: Camera literally on ground or very close. More extreme than low angle. Creates maximum distortion.

vertical_angles.character_perception: Mentally unstable, in wrong world, disoriented, chaotic
vertical_angles.power_dynamic: World is unstable, no clear power relationship
vertical_angles.technical_notes: Tilt camera on roll axis. Subtle (5-15°) for unease, extreme (30-45°) for chaos. Easy to overuse, becomes cliché.

horizontal_angles.psychological_effect: Confrontation, direct address, engagement, honesty (or deception)
horizontal_angles.character_perception: Confident, confrontational, or vulnerable (depending on context)
horizontal_angles.technical_notes: Flattens face. Can feel static. Often combined with eye level for neutrality or low angle for power.
Most common horizontal angle. Shows dimensionality. Flattering to most faces. Versatile baseline.
film_examples: Standard angle in almost all films

horizontal_angles.psychological_effect: Classical, formal, distant, two-world division, decisive
horizontal_angles.character_perception: Decisive, classical, distant, formal, moving forward
avoid_when: Need to see facial expressions clearly
horizontal_angles.technical_notes: Shows silhouette. Classical, formal composition. Often for movement across frame. Less common in modern films.

horizontal_angles.degrees: Slight angle, including part of another character
horizontal_angles.character_perception: In relationship with others, conversational, connected
horizontal_angles.audience_feeling: Inside conversation, privy to exchange, relational context
horizontal_angles.technical_notes: Standard dialogue coverage. Shows spatial relationship. Usually 1/3 frame is shoulder. Alternates in shot-reverse-shot.
film_examples: Standard in almost all dialogue scenes

horizontal_angles.technical_notes: Camera becomes character's eyes. Can be handheld for realism. Often followed by reverse showing character's reaction.
film_examples: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly

horizontal_angles.character_perception: Moving forward, mysterious, vulnerable (exposed back), leading
horizontal_angles.technical_notes: Shows back of head/body. Can create mystery before reveal. Vulnerable (can't see threats). Journey/movement emphasis.

angle_combinations.effect: Menacing power with instability - powerful but dangerous/wrong
angle_combinations.usage: Villains in horror/thrillers, corrupted heroes, unstable authority figures

angle_combinations.effect: Extreme vulnerability and distortion - isolated and wrong
angle_combinations.usage: Victims, extreme emotional breakdown, surreal vulnerability

angle_combinations.effect: Direct, honest confrontation - engaged honesty or lies
angle_combinations.usage: Confessions, direct address, breaking fourth wall, interviews

angle_combinations.effect: God's view of perfect order or pattern
angle_combinations.usage: Wes Anderson films, dance choreography, death scenes, fate
Hero introductions, triumphant moments, divine imagery

power_dynamics.shifting_power: Change angles during scene to show power shift

emotional_states.confrontation: Eye level frontal or low angle frontal

psychological_states.subjectivity: POV, extreme angles matching character perception

sources: The Visual Story by Bruce Block
Grammar of the Film Language by Daniel Arijon
Master Shots Vol. 1-3 by Christopher Kenworthy
Film Directing Shot by Shot by Steven Katz
Cinematic Storytelling by Jennifer Van Sijll
metadata.usage_notes: Angles are relative to subject's eye level and facing direction. Degrees are approximate guidelines. Context and story dictate usage. Combine angles with lighting and composition for maximum effect. Breaking conventions should be purposeful.
